sn22.3:4.2: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis near Kuraraghara on Steep Mountain.
sn22.3:4.3: Then the householder Hāliddikāni went up to Venerable Mahākaccāna,
sn22.3:4.4: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn22.3:4.6: “Sir, this was said by the Buddha in the Chapter of the Eights, in ‘The Questions of Māgandiya’:
sn22.3:5.1: ‘After leaving shelter to become an unsettled migrant,
sn22.3:5.2: a sage doesn’t get close to anyone in town.
sn22.3:5.3: Rid of sensual pleasures, expecting nothing,
sn22.3:6.1: How should we see the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement?”
sn22.3:7.1: “Householder, the form element is a shelter for consciousness.
sn22.3:7.2: One whose consciousness is attached to greed for the form element is called a migrant going from shelter to shelter.
sn22.3:7.3: The feeling element is a shelter for consciousness.
sn22.3:7.4: One whose consciousness is attached to greed for the feeling element is called a migrant going from shelter to shelter.
sn22.3:7.5: The perception element is a shelter for consciousness.
sn22.3:7.6: One whose consciousness is attached to greed for the perception element is called a migrant going from shelter to shelter.
sn22.3:7.7: The choices element is a shelter for consciousness.
sn22.3:7.8: One whose consciousness is attached to greed for the choices element is called a migrant going from shelter to shelter.
sn22.3:7.9: That’s how one is a migrant going from shelter to shelter.
sn22.3:8.1: And how is one a migrant without a shelter?
sn22.3:8.2: The Realized One has given up any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for the form element; any attraction, grasping, mental resolve, insistence, and tendencies. He’s cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, exterminated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
sn22.3:8.3: That’s why the Realized One is called a migrant without a shelter.
sn22.3:8.4: The Realized One has given up any desire, greed, relishing, and craving for the feeling element …
sn22.3:8.7: the consciousness element; any attraction, grasping, mental resolve, insistence, and tendencies. He’s cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, exterminated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
sn22.3:8.8: That’s why the Realized One is called a migrant without a shelter.
sn22.3:8.9: That’s how one is a migrant without a shelter.
sn22.3:9.1: And how is one a migrant going from settlement to settlement?
sn22.3:9.2: Being attached to migrating from settlement to settlement in pursuit of sights, one is called a migrant going from settlement to settlement.
sn22.3:9.3: Being attached to migrating from settlement to settlement in pursuit of sounds …
sn22.3:9.7: phenomena, one is called a migrant going from settlement to settlement.
sn22.3:9.8: That’s how one is a migrant going from settlement to settlement.
sn22.3:10.1: And how is one an unsettled migrant?
sn22.3:10.2: The Realized One has given up attachment to migrating from settlement to settlement in pursuit of sights. He’s cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, exterminated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
sn22.3:10.3: That’s why the Realized One is called an unsettled migrant.
sn22.3:10.4: The Realized One has given up attachment to migrating from settlement to settlement in pursuit of sounds …
sn22.3:10.8: phenomena. He’s cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, exterminated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
sn22.3:10.9: That’s why the Realized One is called an unsettled migrant.
sn22.3:10.10: That’s how one is an unsettled migrant.
sn22.3:11.1: And how does one get close to people in town?
sn22.3:11.2: It’s when someone mixes closely with laypeople, sharing their joys and sorrows—happy when they’re happy and sad when they’re sad—and getting involved in their business.
sn22.3:11.3: That’s how one gets close to people in town.
sn22.3:12.1: And how does one not get close to people in town?
sn22.3:12.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t mix closely with laypeople, not sharing their joys and sorrows—not happy when they’re happy or sad when they’re sad—and not getting involved in their business.
sn22.3:12.3: That’s how one doesn’t get close to people in town.
sn22.3:13.1: And how is one not rid of sensual pleasures?
sn22.3:13.2: It’s when someone isn’t rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.
sn22.3:13.3: That’s how one is not rid of sensual pleasures.
sn22.3:14.1: And how is one rid of sensual pleasures?
sn22.3:14.2: It’s when someone is rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.
sn22.3:14.3: That’s how one is rid of sensual pleasures.
sn22.3:15.1: And how does one have expectations?
sn22.3:15.3: ‘In the future, may I be of such form, such feeling, such perception, such choices, and such consciousness!’
sn22.3:16.1: And how does one expect nothing?
sn22.3:16.3: ‘In the future, may I be of such form, such feeling, such perception, such choices, and such consciousness!’
sn22.3:17.1: And how does one argue with people?
sn22.3:17.2: It’s when someone takes part in this sort of discussion:
sn22.3:17.3: ‘You don’t understand this teaching and training.
sn22.3:17.4: I understand this teaching and training.
sn22.3:17.5: What, you understand this teaching and training?
sn22.3:17.8: You said last what you should have said first.
sn22.3:17.9: You said first what you should have said last.
sn22.3:17.10: I stay on topic, you don’t.
sn22.3:17.11: What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved.
sn22.3:17.15: get yourself out of this—if you can!’
sn22.3:17.16: That’s how one argues with people.
sn22.3:18.1: And how does one not argue with people?
sn22.3:18.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t take part in this sort of discussion:
sn22.3:18.3: ‘You don’t understand this teaching and training …
sn22.3:18.4: get yourself out of this—if you can!’
sn22.3:18.5: That’s how one doesn’t argue with people.
sn22.3:19.1: So, householder, that’s how to understand the detailed meaning of what the Buddha said in brief in the Chapter of the Eights, in ‘The Questions of Māgandiya’:
sn22.3:20.1: ‘After leaving shelter to become an unsettled migrant,
sn22.3:20.2: a sage doesn’t get close to anyone in town.
sn22.3:20.3: Rid of sensual pleasures, expecting nothing,
